frameDefinitions: The Behavior of an Evaluee is described in terms of the reaction it deserves from somebody, such as praise, blame or admiration.
An Agent performs an Action incorrectly.
An Agent ceases an Activity without completing it. '' 'After the lawsuit, the company stopped producing the once very profitable toy.'
An Agent produces a Forgery, an entity that they intend to pass off as a particular (instance of)  a Standard.
A Self_mover leaves an initial Source location.
A Destroyer (a conscious entity) or Cause (an event, or an entity involved in such an event) affects the Patient negatively so that the Patient no longer exists.
frameExamples: It was <t>honorable</t> of you to help that person.
After the lawsuit, the company <t>stopped</t> producing the once very profitable toy.
So who was it that <t>faked</t> the photo 'showing' Jane Fonda and John Kerry with the Vietcong?
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Behavior</fen> of the <fen>Evaluee</fen> is being judged as worthy of a particular reaction.
This role indicates the <fen>Behavior</fen> on which the assessment of praiseworthiness is based.
The <fen>Agent</fen> performs an action incorrectly.
<fen>Patient</fen> is the entity affected by the <fen>Agent</fen>'s bungling of an <fen>Action</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Action</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> performs incorrectly.
The type of action that the <fen>Agent</fen> habitually bungles.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the bungling occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the bungling occurs.
This role identifies <fen>Agent</fen> that stops the <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Activity</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> stops.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> stops the <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> stops the <fen>Activity</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person that creates a Forgery with the intent of passing it off as (an instance of) the <fen>Standard</fen>.
The <fen>Forgery</fen> is the product that the <fen>Agent</fen> creates with the intent of passing it off as (an instance of) the <fen>Standard</fen>.
The <fen>Standard</fen> is the actually existing or imagined (kind of) thing that the <fen>Agent</fen> wants to pass the <fen>Forgery</fen> off as.
The time at which the forgery takes place.
The location in which the <fen>Agent</fen> makes a <fen>Forgery</fen>.
This is the entity which moves under its own power.

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. In particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
The time at which the motion takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.
The conscious entity, generally a person, that performs the intentional action that results in the <fen>Patient</fen>'s destruction.
The entity which is destroyed by the <fen>Destroyer</fen>.
The event or entity which is responsible for the destruction of the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Destroyer</fen> destroys the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Destroyer</fen> destroys the <fen>Patient</fen>.
listRoleExamples: It was commendable <fex>of Lisa</fex> to give so much to charity.
The Austro-Hungarian Empire had a long history of <fex>military</fex> screw-ups.
<fex>The subsequent explosions</fex> leveled most downtown office buildings.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the King James Version of Matthew
the previous thousand years or so
